title: R42792
content: Foster care is a temporary living arrangement for children who cannot safely remain in their own homes. The child welfare agency's goal is to provide necessary services for the child to return to their parents. If reunification is not possible, the agency works to find a permanent home through adoption or legal guardianship. States receive federal funding for child welfare services under Title IV-E of the Social Security Act. The Title IV-E program provides federal reimbursement for foster care, adoption assistance, and kinship guardianship to eligible children. In FY2011, states spent $12.4 billion under the program and received federal reimbursement of $6.7 billion. The program is administered by the Children's Bureau at the federal level and by state child welfare agencies at the state level. The child welfare agency, part of the state's human services department, administers the Title IV-E program. State agencies oversee the program, with two-thirds of funds supporting foster care. Most children receiving adoption assistance were previously in foster care. The report discusses how children enter foster care, state requirements for federal funds, and authorized uses of Title IV-E dollars. The majority of the report focuses on Title IV-E program eligibility criteria and spending specific to foster care maintenance payments, adoption assistance, and kinship guardianship assistance. Child welfare agencies conduct around 2 million family investigations annually to address child abuse or neglect concerns, with neglect being the most common issue reported. Investigative caseworkers often find underlying factors like high stress, low social support, and financial difficulties that contribute to child abuse/neglect investigations. After investigations, 87.1% of children remain at home, 6.1% are in informal kinship arrangements, and 6.3% are in formal out-of-home placements. Risk factors for child abuse and neglect include high stress in the family, low social support, financial difficulties, substance abuse, history of domestic violence, mental health problems, and caregiver arrest. These factors are more common in families where children are removed from the home after an investigation. There was no significant difference in the presence of domestic violence in families where children were removed or remained in the home. The Title IV-E program funds foster care maintenance payments to provide financial assistance for children in foster care. The goal is to reunite children with their parents, but funding can only be used for services for children who meet eligibility criteria. Post-reunification services are not covered by Title IV-E funding. States may rely on various federal funding streams, such as Title IV-B and other sources like TANF and SSBG, to support child welfare programs. Title IV-E funds adoption and kinship guardianship assistance to establish new permanent families for children who cannot return home. Under Title IV-E, states provide financial assistance to eligible children after they leave foster care for adoption or kinship guardianship. Post-adoption or post-guardianship support services are not covered by Title IV-E funds, but can be supported by child welfare programs under Title IV-B, TANF, and SSBG. The Title IV-E program, authorized for Indian tribes since FY2010, requires tribes to meet similar program requirements as states to receive funding. Only one tribe had an approved tribal Title IV-E program as of early September 2012, but more tribes are working towards approval.
